title: Matrix Rank: Row and Column Rank
contentHtml: In linear algebra, the rank of a matrix is a fundamental concept that helps us understand the number of independent rows or columns in the matrix.

theorem.proofSketch: The proof involves showing that the row rank is an upper bound for the column rank, and then using a similar argument to show that the column rank is an upper bound for the row rank.

intuition: In essence, the rank of a matrix represents the maximum number of linearly independent rows or columns. This concept has significant implications in machine learning, as it helps us understand the dimensionality of our data and the number of features that are relevant to our model.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Matrix Rank Theorem
contentHtml: The matrix rank theorem is a fundamental concept in linear algebra that helps us understand the relationship between row and column ranks of a matrix.
intuition: The theorem states that the rank of a matrix is equal to the minimum of its row rank and column rank. This means that if we have multiple linearly independent rows or columns, the rank will be the number of these independent components.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, this theorem has applications in dimensionality reduction, feature selection, and data compression.
